sn22.81:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn22.81:4.2: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Kosambi for alms.
sn22.81:4.3: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he set his lodgings in order himself. Taking his bowl and robes, without informing his attendants or taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha, he set out to go wandering alone, with no companion.
sn22.81:5.1: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, one of the mendicants went to Venerable Ānanda
sn22.81:5.2: and told him what had happened.
sn22.81:5.4: Ānanda said: “Reverend, when the Buddha leaves like this it means he wants to stay alone.
sn22.81:5.5: At this time no-one should follow him.”
sn22.81:6.1: Then the Buddha, travelling stage by stage, arrived at Pārileyya,
sn22.81:6.2: where he stayed at the root of a sacred sal tree.
sn22.81:6.3: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Ānanda
sn22.81:6.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side
sn22.81:6.7: “Reverend, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
sn22.81:6.8: We wish to hear a Dharma talk from the Buddha.”
sn22.81:7.1: Then Venerable Ānanda together with those mendicants went to Pārileyya to see the Buddha.
sn22.81:7.2: They bowed and sat down to one side,
sn22.81:7.3: and the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dharma talk.
sn22.81:7.4: Now at that time one of the monks had the thought:
sn22.81:7.5: “How do you know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life?”
sn22.81:7.6: Then the Buddha, knowing what that monk was thinking, addressed the mendicants:
sn22.81:7.8: I’ve analytically taught the four kinds of mindfulness meditation,
sn22.81:7.10: the four bases of psychic power,
sn22.81:7.15: That’s how I’ve taught the Dharma analytically.
sn22.81:7.16: Though I’ve taught the Dharma analytically, still a certain mendicant present here has this thought:
sn22.81:7.17: ‘How do you know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life?’
sn22.81:8.1: And how, mendicants, do you know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life?
sn22.81:8.2: Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in their teaching. They regard form as self.
sn22.81:8.3: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon.
sn22.81:8.4: And what’s the source, origin, birthplace, and root of that conditioned phenomenon?
sn22.81:8.5: When an uneducated ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.
sn22.81:8.6: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.
sn22.81:8.7: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:8.10: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:8.11: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life.
sn22.81:9.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form as self,
sn22.81:9.2: but they still regard self as possessing form.
sn22.81:9.3: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon. …
sn22.81:10.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form,
sn22.81:10.2: but they still regard form in self.
sn22.81:10.3: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon. …
sn22.81:11.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form, or form in self,
sn22.81:11.2: but they still regard self in form.
sn22.81:11.3: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon. …
sn22.81:12.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form as self, or self as possessing form, or form in self, or self in form.
sn22.81:12.2: But they regard feeling as self …
sn22.81:12.6: But that regarding is just a conditioned phenomenon.
sn22.81:12.7: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon?
sn22.81:12.9: When an uneducated ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.
sn22.81:12.10: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.
sn22.81:12.11: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:12.15: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:12.16: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life.
sn22.81:13.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form or feeling or perception
sn22.81:13.4: Still, they have such a view:
sn22.81:13.5: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:13.6: But that eternalist view is just a conditioned phenomenon.
sn22.81:13.7: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon? …
sn22.81:13.8: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life.
sn22.81:14.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form or feeling
sn22.81:14.5: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:14.6: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:14.7: Still, they have such a view:
sn22.81:14.8: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.81:14.9: But that annihilationist view is just a conditioned phenomenon.
sn22.81:14.10: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon? …
sn22.81:14.14: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life.
sn22.81:15.1: Perhaps they don’t regard form or feeling
sn22.81:15.5: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:15.6: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
sn22.81:15.7: Nor do they have such a view:
sn22.81:15.8: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.81:15.9: Still, they have doubts and uncertainties. They’re undecided about the true teaching.
sn22.81:15.10: That doubt and uncertainty, the indecision about the true teaching, is just a conditioned phenomenon.
sn22.81:15.11: And what’s the source of that conditioned phenomenon?
sn22.81:15.12: When an uneducated ordinary person is struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, craving arises.
sn22.81:15.13: That conditioned phenomenon is born from that.
sn22.81:15.14: So that conditioned phenomenon is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:15.18: and that ignorance are also impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated.
sn22.81:15.19: That’s how you should know and see in order to end the defilements in the present life.”
